SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<headline>
Jeb Bush on Brother George W: He Kept Us Safe
</headline>
<post id="p1" author="Thoughts R Us" datetime="2015-06-02T04:52:00">

Jeb Bush has become quite the comedian these days. First he says that even knowing what we know about the outcome in Iraq, he would do it all over again. Of course maybe he was on to something with regards to winning the Republican nomination...a very recent poll showed that Republican voters are the only ones who still believe that invading Iraq was the right thing to do.
Now in a question on the CBS show Face the Nation to assess the successes and failures of his brother's presidency, Jeb says that dear old brother "kept us safe"...
Of course Jeb ignores the 9-11 attacks, only the biggest terror attack on the US homeland in history. For the Republicans, anything before 9-11 doesn't count.

Jeb also ignores the loss of American lives in the needless and disastrous war in Iraq, for which GW deserves responsibility. Jeb also ignores the loss of American lives due to the Bush mismanagement of the war in Afghanistan.
Then there's Katrina...but I guess to a Republican safety doesn't count if it's poor black people getting hurt in a natural disaster.
Bush did say this about learning from his brother's mistakes:

"And I think I learned also from not having -- keeping the reins on spending. Because of the war and because of the focus on protecting the homeland, I think he let the Republican Congress get a little out of control in terms of the spending."

So yes, poor old GW just got run over by that Republican congress. GW would never have spent all those billions on his own war of choice. So we can infer that Jeb Bush will go to war, he'll just somehow be more thrifty about it.

George W.'s wars weren't the only unpopular policy for which Jeb reiterated his support. He also advocated raising the retirement age for the "supplemental retirement system" (that would be Social Security—words he carefully avoided using) to 68 or 70.
Keep in mind this is not just Jeb Bush talking...these are views that the majority of the Republican party hold.
</post>
<post id="p2" author="mamallama" datetime="2015-06-02T05:35:00">
Jeb Bush has lost it trying to justify the screwup his brother did. He is becoming more a joke as each day passes.
</post>
<post id="p3" author="ZX11" datetime="2015-06-02T05:48:00">

Of course maybe he was on to something with regards to winning the Republican nomination...a very recent poll showed that Republican voters are the only ones who still believe that invading Iraq was the right thing to do.

Bush did say this about learning from his brother's mistakes:

"And I think I learned also from not having -- keeping the reins on spending. Because of the war and because of the focus on protecting the homeland, I think he let the Republican Congress get a little out of control in terms of the spending."

So yes, poor old GW just got run over by that Republican congress. GW would never have spent all those billions on his own war of choice. So we can infer that Jeb Bush will go to war, he'll just somehow be more thrifty about it.

George W.'s wars weren't the only unpopular policy for which Jeb reiterated his support. He also advocated raising the retirement age for the "supplemental retirement system" (that would be Social Security—words he carefully avoided using) to 68 or 70.
Keep in mind this is not just Jeb Bush talking...these are views that the majority of the Republican party hold.
</quote>
That is one view on the events of the early years of the 21st century. So far left, I figure you live in a tent by a marijuana field or wish you did.

I don't think anyone could have stopped the 911 attacks except by attacking Afghanistan first. I think burning down two countries for the 911 attacks, makes it perfectly clear what leaders of other countries risk if they support another attack on the US.
If Mr. Bush traces an attack back to you,... pappa spank!
</post>
<post id="p4" author="bikinchris" datetime="2015-06-02T07:03:00">
<quote orig_author="Thoughts R Us">
Then there's Katrina...but I guess to a Republican safety doesn't count if it's poor black people getting hurt in a natural disaster.
</quote>

Nope, they blame that all on Democratic governor Kathleen Blanco. They claim she never asked for help. In fact, she has a tape where she said she needed every bit of help the federal government could provide. Then they said, "Well, she didn't ask fro specific numbers and type of equipment." In other words, they blamed it on her.
<quote orig_author="ZX11">
That is one view on the events of the early years of the 21st century. So far left, I figure you live in a tent by a marijuana field or wish you did.

I don't think anyone could have stopped the 911 attacks except by attacking Afghanistan first. I think burning down two countries for the 911 attacks, makes it perfectly clear what leaders of other countries risk if they support another attack on the US.
If Mr. Bush traces an attack back to you,... pappa spank!
</quote>

Yes, of course, spank Iraq because...well, because they had weapons of mass destruction. Well, no? Well they had ties to Al Qaeda. No? Al Qaeda wanted Saddam dead? Well why not just kill him ourselves and make it easy for them? Well, just because we wanted to dig another money pit that will never fill up and leave another middle east power vacuum so terrorists can sweep in and build a safe base, just like Afghanistan was when Carter and Reagan left it wide open for the Taliban.
</post>

If Mr. Bush traces an attack back to you,... pappa spank!

Wow, you guys, along with the Russians trashed Afghanistan to the point there was no government, and you blame the country for harboring terrorists?
That truly is comedy.
What rock have you been living under that you didn't hear that there was absolutly no ties between 9/11 and Iraq?
The truth is, if the USA has happen to it that it does to every country that ticks it off, they will invent enemies where none were before, and then trash those countries too.
</post>
<post id="p6" author="ZX11" datetime="2015-06-02T08:10:00">
<quote orig_author="bikinchris">
<quote orig_author="ZX11">
<quote orig_author="bikinchris">
<quote orig_author="Thoughts R Us">
Then there's Katrina...but I guess to a Republican safety doesn't count if it's poor black people getting hurt in a natural disaster.
</quote>

Nope, they blame that all on Democratic governor Kathleen Blanco. They claim she never asked for help. In fact, she has a tape where she said she needed every bit of help the federal government could provide. Then they said, "Well, she didn't ask fro specific numbers and type of equipment." In other words, they blamed it on her.
</quote>
That is one view on the events of the early years of the 21st century. So far left, I figure you live in a tent by a marijuana field or wish you did.

I don't think anyone could have stopped the 911 attacks except by attacking Afghanistan first. I think burning down two countries for the 911 attacks, makes it perfectly clear what leaders of other countries risk if they support another attack on the US.
If Mr. Bush traces an attack back to you,... pappa spank!
</quote>

Yes, of course, spank Iraq because...well, because they had weapons of mass destruction. Well, no? Well they had ties to Al Qaeda. No? Al Qaeda wanted Saddam dead? Well why not just kill him ourselves and make it easy for them? Well, just because we wanted to dig another money pit that will never fill up and leave another middle east power vacuum so terrorists can sweep in and build a safe base, just like Afghanistan was when Carter and Reagan left it wide open for the Taliban.
</quote>

I will give you that. Iraq was better off under Saddam's rule. Freedom/democracy isn't good for all cultures, in hindsight. And he kept internal fanatics and power hungry factions under control. Definitely not a friend of religious fanatics.
The presence of WMD's beyond those chemicals Iraq used on the Kurds wasn't known for sure one way or the other. Everyone knew he had tried to build a nuclear plant but not sure why.

His push back on UN inspectors forced the issue. His push back in combination with the US not being willing to ignore intel that an attack on the US was being planned by Iraq. 911 made the US less willing to take a first strike before reacting. He perhaps had to show strength to the US to maintain internal power so the conflict was going to happen anyway.

The bad part is the US stayed in country to try to rebuild it. Should have just left and let it work itself out. Knowing we could wipe them in 30 days or less if they chose to point their guns at us or Kuwait, again. Hence my point on "pappa spank". Spank them and leave if they invade a neighbor or refuse inspectors as a defeated country (part of the Desert Storm peace agreement).
</post>

Of course maybe he was on to something with regards to winning the Republican nomination...a very recent poll showed that Republican voters are the only ones who still believe that invading Iraq was the right thing to do.

One of the problems of this era of American politics is that we confuse family/national loyalty with clear thinking. Jeb Bush is not only trying to 'stand with his clan/family', but represent the United States in the world. He might win a few points from the clueless sops of 'America, love it or leave it' crowd, but god help us if he won and put it into our national policy. His brother did a really bang up job didn't he?
</post>
